headline: Toasted Pumpkin Seeds with Sugar and Spice
description: This is a delicious unique variation of toasted pumpkin seeds. The seeds are actually candied and then tossed with pumpkin pie spice, sugar and salt. Easy to prepare and hard to mess up. Once you start eating them, you won't be able to stop!
name: Toasted Pumpkin Seeds with Sugar and Spice
recipeIngredient: 1 cup raw pumpkin seeds, rinsed and dried

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F (120 degrees C). Spread pumpkin seeds in a single layer on a baking sheet. Toast for 45 minutes, stirring occasionally, until dry and toasted. Larger seeds may take longer.

In a large bowl, stir together 2 tablespoons of white sugar, salt, and pumpkin pie spice. Set aside. Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the pumpkin seeds and sprinkle the remaining sugar over them. Stir with a wooden spoon until the sugar melts, about 45 seconds. Pour seeds into the bowl with the spiced sugar and stir until coated. Allow to cool before serving. Store in an airtight container at room temperature.

review.reviewBody: I used coconut oil and pure cane sugar...came out amazing!!! I did not cook the seeds in the pan at all and it still had the perfect crunch...seems like an unnecessary step (from one of the popular reviews).
Replaced a bit of oil with 2 tsp butter, added a little cinnamon to the pumpkin spice. Yummy and kids loved
Soooo delicious!!!!! Best recipe I’ve tried yet!
Excellent recipe! Yum!
My kids loved it
These are crazy good. I used pumpkin seed oil and it worked just great.
Followed the recipe exactly and it turned out so yummy! AND SO SIMPLE!!! Made this for an after school/Pre-Halloween treat and decided I better eat some NOW because this definitely won't last long!
Not the taste I was expecting but it’s alright. Hubby didn’t like the taste at all and my daughter said it taste like peanuts.

I double checked twice. It actually says six TABLEspoons sugar. I barely used TWO and it was way too much. Could do two TBSP with the recommended spices and about 2-3 cups seeds (not one) and it would be just right..
I made it Just like it says and they’re so good!
Delicious! This recipe basically makes candied pumpkin seeds, very similar to the spiced nuts you see in kiosks at the mall.

this recipe is amazing! the only thing that everyone was not so sure about was all of the sugar on the seeds. i had to double the recipe so i don't know if that's what caused it or if it was something else. otherwise they were amazing!!
Easy recipe for delicious, sweet toasted pumpkin seeds. They remind me of candied nuts.
easy yummy 1st time eating sweet pumpkin seeds always make salty, this was awesome cant stop eating them, will definately make more next time, hard to share.

Super simple recipe that was easy to adapt to the small amount of Squash seeds I had (1/2 cup). I feel like the surgar could be reduced. I added just a touch of Cayenne pepper to a small portion of the seeds, love the sweet heat!

Made the recipe as is. 

I liked them, our kids didn't. Sweet & salty. Delicious!!! Only thing, I kept them in the pan until they started browning.... they tasted slightly burnt but I really didn't mind. Super crunchy for when you want a little snack! Will definitely make these again. Next time, I'll need a bigger pumpkin!!!
Kiersten loved it. I did cook it at 275 degrees for 1 hour though.

These were amazing! I only used about 3 Tbs of sugar. I used 1 Tbs for the salt, and pumpkin pie spice mixture. I also put 4 Tbs of sugar in a small tea cup and sprinkled over the pumpkin seeds while cooking in the oil. I only used half of it. These are delicious and need to buy another pumpkin for some more seeds!

I had tons of seeds so I tripled this recipe. Perhaps it's not agreeable to that. 
I agree with many other reviewers that the amount of sugar seems off. "Sprinkle remaining sugar" is deceiving...there's way too much for a sprinkle. And it didn't budge in 45 seconds. I had to keep stirring as it smoked and the seeds browned... It never fully desolved and the seeds started getting into huge chunks (another reviewer said it's like peanut brittle...I agree). I had to finally take it off the heat because I didn't want the seeds to burn. Then I dumped it into MORE sugar...it was just insane. Wish it had more pumpkin spice too. 

The only reason I didn't give it lower stars is because the flavor is decent...it's just that they are clumped together with huge amounts of unmelted sugar coating them...not at all the texture I was expecting. (After posting this I went back and looked at the pictures...would have helped to do that ahead of time as most recipes looked like mine did. I guess the granulated sugar coating is the desired outcome.)
I loved this recipe! My kids ate the seeds for the first time in years! I will use a little less sugar next time because there was alot that did not stay on the seeds.
I have tried a few recipes and this one is fail proof. Yummy!
I think these turned out yummy. Wish I'd toasted a little longer, but, for my first time, not bad!!

This is the first time in many years we cooked pumpkin seeds and they were actually enjoyed. We had more seeds than the recipe calls for, but it was still plenty sweet. My 2 year old called them "little cookies"
This is an excellent recipe. They were so easy to make and once you start eating them it's impossible to stop!
Yum yum YUM! These are sooo addictive and there are NEVER enough seeds from our pumpkins!
Yum yum YUM! These are sooo addictive and there are NEVER enough seeds from our pumpkins!

Love them! I made 2 changes, one of necessity. I didn't have enough white sugar so I put 2Tbsp brown sugar in the skillet to melt. The other I've found I prefer butter in my pumpkin seeds so I put 1/2 Tbsp butter and 1 Tbsp olive oil.

Love these! I was a bit skeptical at first bc normally I would bake the sugar and spices on the seeds but I tried a recipe last year and they did not come out well. So I decided to try this one this year bc of its high reviews and wow! it did not disappoint! Sweet but with a slight salty finish. The seeds are crunchy and not chewy. Great Flavors!! I highly recommend this recipe!

These were amazing, I could not stop eating them. I am usually a savory toasted pumpkin seed girl with a little salt and some garlic powder. But I think these have changed that forever! I also just mixed everything together with only 3 Tbsp. of sugar and baked at 350 for about 30 mins. Stirring every 10 mins. I have to go out and get more pumpkins so I can scoop out the seeds and make more of them this way!
Yummy!
These are great! I only used 4 TBS of sugar though. I think 6 would be too much.
Was very nice, though I think I added too much sugar. Came out too sweet for my taste!
Great as is!
Very good!! Also easy!

I've have tried making a lot of different pumpkin seed recipes, this is by far my favorite!!! The only change I made is to soak the freshly scooped out and cleaned pumpkin seeds in salt water for 1 hour before drying off and spreading on the sheet pan ( this gave it the sweet and salty effect). My search is over, this will be my go to from here on out!

Followed it exactly and it turned out fantastic. 

And I think I might start adding a little clove and nutmeg to my cinnamon sugar.
Yum! My very first time making pumpkin seeds and this was easy and wonderful. I did make it with less sugar because I am trying to cut sugar and I used butter instead of oil. Thank you for sharing.
All I can say is delicious.
These were Amazing. I'm not a big sweet nuts fan but figured it was different so I'd give it a try. Delicious. Best pumpkin seeds I ever had.
Excellent!

I'm giving this 5 stars because it is amazing, with a LOT less sugar and I want to make sure people try it. As it stands, I could have never eaten it with that much sugar and probably would have rated it 2 stars. 

Here's what I did: I used 2 T Splenda in the coating mix (with salt and pumpkin pie spice made from the Pumpkin Pie Spice II recipe on allrecipes). In the frying pan, I used 1 T olive oil and sprinkled about 1-2 T sugar on it, stirring for about 2-3 minutes until the sugar melted. Then I tossed it into the coating mix. It was definitely sweet enough and the seeds are amazingly addictive!

I, like many other reviewers, have never really liked pumpkin seeds. My first grader had some at school and wanted to make them so we tried this. I am a convert! Loved this recipe and our family ate them up quickly. There was a lot of topping, you could probably cut back on that and still get good results
So nummy. Only made one change -- used coconut oil instead of vegetable oil. It's a little healthier and adds a lovely flavor!
Soooo good!! I used coconut oil instead of olive oil, and truvia baking blend rather than just sugar to try to be a little healthy. Also added coconut flakes. Amazing.
If you are looking for a sweet pumpkin seed recipe, this one is a keeper! They were delicious! I followed the recipe exactly. It was simple to make too. Yum!!

Extremely delicious! It was hard to stop nibbling on these pumpkin seeds. Perfectly crisp, just enough salt to bring out the sweet flavors. Seeds for a second batch are in the oven. I don't buy pumpkin pie spice, so I used 1/4 tsp cinnamon, 1/8 tsp ginger, 1/8 tsp nutmeg, and a pinch of cloves. I may have been a bit generous in my spice measurements since we like it spicy. As I was mixing, the ginger vapors were pretty strong. If you are sensitive, you may not want to inhale over the bowl until it cools.
First time making toasted pumpkin seeds and everyone liked them. Will definitely make them again using this recipe.

These turned out great, definitely have to dry them first! Taste was very sweet, I used brown sugar rather than white and I think it gave it a richer taste. I would increase the salt,but otherwise a great recipe. Keeper for sure.
Quick and easy. This is the first pumpkin seed recipe that I've liked!

Very addictive. I had to increase to 300 degrees and use a cookie sheet to get them crispy but other then that the family is loving them. Next time I may increase the salts as others suggested but great as is.
Easy and delicious!
We have been cooking seeds for years with just salt on them. This is a great twist on baked seeds with a terrific taste. Thanks. Read a couple of reviews prior to cooking and give it a whirl.

This was the best batch of pumpkin seeds I ever made. They ended up perfectly coated, and a great balance of sugar, spice and saltiness. I did add a tbsp of butter to the oil and sugar, because it just didn't seem like it was coming together correctly. Perhaps it would have if I waited long enough. It appears that other reviewers had issue with this step as well.
My family loves this recipe. I've tried other pumpkin seed recipes, but we keep coming back to this one. Sweet with just a little spice flavor. Mmmmm...
This is a keeper. I thought it would be too sweet, but it was just right. Addictive, actually. I plan to try this with other nuts and maybe popcorn.

This was my first time cooking a pumpkin and I knew you could eat the seeds. This was really nice...possibly a bit too much sugar. Very bad for my teeth but I thought surely it doesn't matter this once? lol I enjoyed making this
Soooo good!!!!!!

I used almost 2 cups of seeds, and only 5 tbs of sugar, half of it truvia... 

The seeds weren't too crisp, so I did them for another 20 minutes at 275 degrees.

Turned out great - Pumpkin Pie Seeds!
Oh Lawd! This was like crack cocaine. I left the seeds on my counter for several weeks before I had time to cook them, but no bother. They came out perfect.

Baked at 300F instead (because I was doing another pumpkin seed recipe at the same time). I didn't have pumpkin pie spice so I used cinnamon and ginger. In the skillet I used butter instead of oil. Came out really nice, thanks for the recipe!
Super tasty. My kids couldn't get enough & neither could my husband and I. Yum!
Delicious!!
We loved this recipe! I did some savory ones also, and this recipe won hands down. I did decrease the sugar by a couple Tablespoons also.Very yummy!

Great receipe! Definitely different from the typical salted seeds. I mixed all ingredients together and baked them as other reviewer had and although the baking time was a little longer I achieved the same results. I suggest using parchment paper though, as I lost one pan of seeds which stuck to the cookie sheet.
This was awesome! I never liked pumpkin seeds but this recipe made them tolerable! They were sweet and salty at the same time. Great recipe!
Very Good. Could use less sugar and still come out the same.
This is so good!! I love the mix of sweet and salty, it makes for the perfect halloween movie snack. I used cinnamon instead of pumpkin spice because I didn't have it and it turned out great!

Delicious! We took a bunch of these to a picnic with friends, and everyone raved. The kids couldn't stop eating them... One adjustment, as recommended in some reviews, we cut down on the amount of sugar during the cooking. For a double batch, we cooked in oil with 5T sugar (not 8). Still plenty sweet. We will definitely make these again!

Delicious! I used butter instead of oil because I wanted the sugar to caramelize and I wasn't sure it was going to work with oil. Makes me want to make more jack-o-lanterns just so I can roast the seeds!

These turned out great! I will totally be making these again next year. I did make a few changes. I used butter instead of oil. Also I used a combo of cinnamon/ginger/nutmeg because I didn't have pumpkin pie spice on hand. I also added a tad more salt. Delicious!!
Yummy, can't stop eating them!
These we're 'eh'. I liked the flavor, but they didn't seem to really "roast". May try again and experiment a bit with cooking variations.
Not the best.

I loved this one! I had never thought to make pumpkin seeds sweet and salty. I had rave reviews when I brought some to a family get toghether. I was wishing I had more pumpkin seeds so I could make more.
I wasn't sure at first how these were turning out, but when they cooled they had a beautiful sugary crust and were delicious.
Best pumpkin seeds EVER!

Delicious!! Tastes a bit like popcorn, and the sugar and spice is just perfect. Can't believe I've thrown seeds away for years. I read somewhere that winter squash seeds can be used too. Very nutritious snack, will be making this every fall!
Yum! Love these kettle-corn type treat!
Oh, YUM! Made about 1/2 the recipe and didn't follow the method precisely. Still fabulous!
Love these crunchy treats. Always go fast.
These pumpkin seeds were amazing! I added nutmeg and extra cinamon to make them more spice tasting! Husband ate so much that i will have to double the next batch!

Although I will eat roasted pumpkin seeds, I am not usually a big enough fan that I go to the effort of making them as easy as they are (especially when my chickens enjoy them as they are). Well, I decided to try these with my family and then make them with them with the preschoolers I teach if they turned out well. I am glad I did; these were terrific! They reminded me of kettle corn with pumpkin spice and it worked very well! I am now a big fan of toasted pumpkin seeds and I know several others that now are too. I will make these each year when making my pie pumpkins and/or when carving pumpkins. I too used less sugar (cut down by 2 TBLS.) and it was plenty. Thank you for a great recipe!
I loved this too! My family ate them up fast. I too reduced the sugar to 4 tablespoons and used butter instead of oil as well. They do taste like snickerdoodles!
These were pretty good. I cut down on the sugar and still had a lot wasted at the bottom of the bowl, but these have a really nice flavor.

My previous attempt at roasted pumpkin seeds didn't go over nearly as well as this recipe. Even my eight-year-old gobbled them up. I think one key is to toast them until they are light and crispy. You can tell a difference when you are stirring them in the pan. Took about an hour for our batch. Only problem I encountered was that the plain sugar did not really "melt" in the skillet to coat the seeds the way I imagined. But they still took on enough flavor from the spiced sugar to be considered a success.
Yummy!!! Thank you for the recipe

I soaked the seeds overnight in salted water. Then layed out on paper towels to dry out. I doubled the recipe as i had 2 cups of seeds and it turned out GREAT!! Really crispy and very tasty! Family loved them!!

These were so good! I did it the easy way. After letting the seeds dry out over night, I just tossed them with the rest of the ingredients and toasted them in the oven at 275 for 35-40 min. I used 2 cups of pumpkin seeds and only 5 tablespoons of sugar. Awesome! I never liked pumpkin seeds until I made them this way.
I used cinnamon instead of pumpkin pie spice

Great flavor combo! I did tweak things, based on other reviews and the first batch we did. Ultimately the fave was using butter for the oil, and only one T. of sugar in the pan. I also melted the butter/sugar before adding in the seeds...stirred them enough to make sure they were coated, then put them in the dry sugar mixture. And for that, doubled the pumpkin pie spice as well as the salt. I love savory pumpkin seeds, but this might be the family's new fave!
For a tasty treat, use brown sugar instead of white... mmmmmmmmmm!

I added some allspice and ground cloves and just a dash of ground ginger. These pumpkin seeds are excellent! Not splintery like others and the flavor is so great! Don't omit the salt as it really makes the flavors come together! I agree that's they're hard to stop eating!
Wasn't a pumpkin seed fan until this recipe. It is fabulous made just as directed!

AWESOME... I roasted them on parchment paper, so they wouldn't stick to the baking sheet. I cut the sugar to 4tbsp like someone else suggested, and doubled the pumpkin spice because I'm crazy that way.
Look no further...this is a great recipe! I put this into my recepie box for next Halloween.

New family tradition! Each year my family roasts the pumpkin seeds from our Jack O'Lanterns and we've used various recipes...all of which were good, but unmemorable. This is a fantastic spin on our tradition, mixing a sweet taste with a salty kick. Wish Halloween came around more than once a year!

These were addicting! I baked them for 1 hour at 275 until they were crispy. I followed the direction except for reducing the sugar in the spice mixture by 2 Tbsp. I think there was still too much grainy sugar on the seeds; next time I might just add everything in the pan so it actually sticks to the seeds.
these are awesome. Would have given them 5 stars but you do need to back off on the sugar by at least half. I used exactly 3 tbs and that was way to much. Will make these again.
Really good! It tastes a bit like kettle corn. That little hint of salt really compliments it.
